title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals of Casting & Splinting
description: Assess your understanding of the history, chemistry, and fundamental principles of casting.

questions.question: What is the primary chemical reaction that occurs when water is added to Plaster of Paris?
questions.explanation: The reaction is exothermic: $$ 2(CaSO_4 \cdot \frac{1}{2}H_2O) + 3H_2O \rightarrow 2(CaSO_4 \cdot 2H_2O) + Heat $$. This release of heat explains why the cast feels warm as it sets.
questions.hint: Think about what you feel when the plaster starts to set.

questions.question: Match the historical figure with their contribution to casting:

pairs.right: Quoted: 'Things heal faster in the plaster'

questions.explanation: Mathijsen popularized POP bandages; Pare used early stiffened molds; Howard emphasized healing in plaster; Hippocrates used early splinting methods.
questions.hint: Mathijsen is associated with the modern POP bandage era.

questions.question: Which of the following factors DECREASE the setting time of Plaster of Paris (accelerate setting)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hot water, Salt, Borax, and Resin decrease setting time. Cold water and Sugar increase (slow) the setting time.
questions.hint: Think about what you would add to make a reaction happen faster.

questions.question: The chemical formula for Gypsum is ___BLANK___, which is converted to Plaster of Paris by heating.
questions.hint: It contains Calcium, Sulfur, Oxygen, and Water.

questions.question: Arrange the stages of Plaster of Paris setting in chronological order:
questions.explanation: The process moves from mixing -> Initial Set (<10m) -> Final Set (10-45m) -> Hard Set (24-72h).
questions.hint: Start with mixing and end with the fully dry cast.

questions.question: Synthetic casts (fiberglass) are generally heavier and less water-resistant than Plaster of Paris casts.
questions.explanation: Synthetic casts are LIGHTER, stronger, and MORE water-resistant than Plaster of Paris.
questions.hint: Consider why modern materials might be preferred for active patients.

questions.question: Review the definitions table below. Which term correctly matches the definition 'Incorporates part or the entire trunk of the body and a part or all of one or more extremities'?

richContent.content:
TermCategory
SlabPartial circumference
CastFull circumference
???Trunk + Extremity

questions.explanation: A Spica cast incorporates the trunk and an extremity (e.g., Hip Spica, Shoulder Spica).

questions.question: What is the term for the time taken for the cast to change from crystalline form to anhydrous form (fully dry)?
questions.explanation: Drying Time is the time to become anhydrous (24-72 hours), distinct from Setting Time.

questions.question: Identify the disadvantages of Plaster of Paris from the list below: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: POP is heavy, not waterproof, takes long to dry, but is inexpensive and easy to mold. It is relatively radiopaque compared to synthetics.
questions.hint: Think about the comfort of the patient.

questions.question: What is the primary function of a cast?

options.text: To rigidly protect an injured bone and hold alignment
To allow immediate full range of motion
To serve as a permanent prosthetic

questions.explanation: The cast's main function is rigid protection and maintenance of alignment for healing.
questions.hint: Why do we put a broken bone in a hard shell?

questions.question: The mineral Gypsum is mined extensively in the ___BLANK___ district of France, giving Plaster of Paris its name.
questions.explanation: The Montmartre district in Paris is famous for its gypsum deposits.
questions.hint: It's a famous hill in Paris.

questions.question: The reaction of Plaster of Paris is reversible.
questions.explanation: Yes, gypsum can be calcined to make POP, and POP reacts with water to reform gypsum crystals.
questions.hint: Can we turn the powder back into a hard stone?

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an indication for casting?
questions.explanation: Acute compartment syndrome requires DECOMPRESSION (removing constrictions), not casting which causes constriction.
questions.hint: Which condition is caused by pressure?
